definition[0]: low in temperature, but not cold, often in a way that feels pleasant
example[0]: She swam out into the cool water.
example[2]: Relax in the sun with a cool drink.
definition[1]: clothing that is cool is made of thin material so that you do not become too hot
definition[2]: calm and not nervous, upset, or excited
example[5]: She looks efficient and as cool as a cucumber.
example[6]: Outwardly she is cool, calm, and collected.
example[7]: a cool customer (=someone who always behaves calmly)
example[9]: his ability to keep cool in a crisis
definition[3]: very attractive, fashionable, interesting etc in a way that people admire – used in order to show approval
definition[4]: used to say that you agree with something, that you understand it, or that it does not annoy you
example[14]: OK, Ryan, that’s cool, I can do it.
example[15]: ‘I just have to go, you know.’ ‘It’s all right, it’s cool.’
example[17]: My mum was cool about whatever I wore.
example[18]: Is Friday cool with you guys?
example[19]: ‘Do you want to come over and watch a video tonight?’ ‘I’m cool with that.’
definition[5]: behaving in a way that is not as friendly as you expect
example[20]: My proposal met with a cool response.
example[21]: Luke gave her a cool look.
definition[6]: a cool colour is one, such as blue or green, that makes you think of cool things
definition[7]: to make something slightly colder, or to become slightly colder
example[22]: The air conditioning doesn’t seem to be cooling the room much.
example[23]: Allow the biscuits to cool for five minutes.
definition[8]: if a feeling, emotion, or relationship cools, it becomes less strong
example[25]: The affair had cooled, on her side at least.
example[26]: When tempers had cooled, he apologized.
